title: ASIC case puts general advice on life support
text:
Justice Jacqueline Gleeson backed that view in December 2018 in the original case. While she found Westpac failed in its duty to provide financial services ‘‘efficiently, honestly and fairly’’, she said Westpac’s campaign did not stray into the category of personal advice.

But the appeal judges ruled Westpac’s campaign should have taken into account customers’ personal circumstances and so did constitute personal advice.

The judges cited a few key problems with the Westpac campaign.

Allsop wrote in his judgment that the Westpac push to ‘‘close’’ the transaction on the phone and get the customer to consolidate their accounts with BT involved an implied recommendation.

Jagot called the whole campaign an example of a ‘‘systemic sharp practice’’, and said the pre-existing relationship between Westpac and the customers meant Westpac would be expected to consider their best interests.

Westpac is disappointed with the decision and is considering an appeal to the High Court. That would be a big step given this is a unanimous judgment.

But for the wider financial advice industry, this case is important in clarifying just how limited general advice is.

Herbert Smith Freehills partner Michael Vrisakis describes it as a ‘‘double whammy for providers of general advice’’.

Advertisement

Even if a product is only recommended through implication, if a customer reasonably believes the institution is looking after their interests, then this judgment says the institution may well have strayed into personal advice.

And if it hasn’t strayed, if the advice relates to a matter of significant financial importance – super is a great example – then you may be found to have not acted efficiently, honestly and fairly, in accordance with the community expectations.

''The more interaction and dialogue you have had or have with the client, the greater the risk,’’ Vrisakis says.

He expects the judgment will reinforce the view for financial providers that they are on safer ground if they shift away from general advice towards the higher standard of personal advice.

Yes, the advice will be more tailored. But this will be much more expensive because it requires the provider to understand the customer’s individual circumstances, ramp up disclosure (typically through a statement of advice) and meet a higher standard of consumer protections.

ASIC is pleased that general advice will be much more narrowly defined – it’s sceptical of how general advice has been used to sell a product (as, it argues, in the Westpac case), and says consumers struggle to tell general and personal advice apart anyway, leading to potential problems.

But what’s the outcome for consumers here?

No one wants consumers exposed to ‘‘sharp practices’’ by institutions. But if general advice is limited to informational, educational material – the sort stuff that ASIC arguably does best itself through its MoneySmart website, but this can be hard for consumers to engage with – should we then be concerned that we are reliant on forms of personal advice that is unaffordable for some, or even many, Australians?

Advertisement

By making the distinction between general and personal advice much more black and white, will a lot of consumers get left in the grey?
description: ASIC's Federal Court win over Westpac on financial advice has big ramifications for the sector.
